author: John Dagge
title: All over for big booms
text:
THE greatest boom in commodity prices Australia is ever likely to witness is well and truly over, Orica’s new chief executive says.
And India will not provide local miners with the same opportunities as China, Alberto Calderon says.
Mr Calderon, a former BHP Billiton heavyweight, also says mining companies need to be far more open to embracing new technology to bolster productivity in a new and more volatile world for the resources industry.
He was speaking yesterday after the Melbourne-based explosives maker issued a shock downgrade to its profit forecast and flagged impairments of up to $1.65 billion.
The bleak update sent the company’s share price into free fall, slumping 17 per cent to close at its lowest level in more than six years.
The bulk of the writedown stems from Orica’s US mining ground support equipment business, for which it paid $870 million in 2006.
Orica is also being hurt by a slowdown in the mining industry and a global oversupply of ammonium nitrate, the main ingredient used in explosives. The oversupply has prompted the group to mothball production capacity.
Net profit for Orica’s 2015 financial year, which finishes next month, is now expected to range from $416.6 million to $441 million, 10 per cent to 15 per cent lower than earlier forecasts.
Mr Calderon, appointed to the top job at Orica in mid May, said mining companies and services suppliers need to adjust to a permanently tougher environment.
“In the new normal we all have to adjust, we all have to work more efficiently and we need to work better together.”
India would not serve as a replacement for China and could even skip the industrialisation phase of its development, he said.
It might instead jump to a services-led, consumption-based economy that would not require massive levels of bulk commodities such as iron ore, Mr Calderon said.
India’s steel consumption would peak at 250 million tonnes annually around 2040 while China’s last year produced 820 million tonnes, he said.
Mr Calderon, who was in the running to take the helm at BHP during his days there, came to Orica after former chief Ian Smith was sacked for aggressive management behaviour.
Orica had a great ingrained culture, Mr Calderon said, and he was determined his management team would live by core values of respect, collaboration and performance.
Shares in the group closed $3.19 lower at $15.64.
